entries.prompt:
Explain  how each  of the following  leads  economists  to believe  that demand  falls for a
particular good as its price rises (that demand is downward sloping):
- Diminishing  marginal  utility
- The income  effect
- The substitution  effect
entries.model_answer:
Explain  how each  of the following  leads  economists  to believe  that demand  falls for a
particular good as its price rises (that demand is downward sloping):
- Diminishing  marginal  utility
- The income  effect
- The substitution  effect
 Diminishing marginal utility suggests that as an individual consumes more of a good, the
utility (pleasure)  that each additional unit  of consumption brings falls. Correspondingly, the
price she  is willing  to pay for each  additional  unit falls, which  therefore  leads  to a downward
sloping  demand curve: higher quantities of demand can only be achieved through lower
prices.
The income effect states that demand is downward sloping because as the price of a good
increases,  the lower  the income  I have  relative  to that price,  and therefore  the less I am
likely  to demand of the higher priced good. The income of individuals is really a relative
concept – the absolute  amount  of your money  is worthless  to you, it is what  it can buy
which  is of significance, and what your money can buy is determined by the price of the
goods you want to buy.
Therefore, as the price of a good rises, your income relatively falls and therefore if you
want to maintain  your consumption  of that good  you can buy fewer  other  goods:  your likely
response  to demand less of the higher priced item.
The substitution  effect  states  that as the price  of one good  rises  relative  to another  good  of
similar design, the  more  we are likely to demand  the second  good, and  therefore  the less
we will demand the good for which the price has risen. This could work in two ways: first,
you may demand the more expensive of two goods, but as the price rises of this the
cheaper version becomes more attractive; or, you may demand the cheaper good, but if
the price of the cheaper good rises, the extra quality of the more expensive good becomes
more attractive: it is the relative price which  is moving which is the most important part
here.
mark_scheme: Explains diminishing marginal utility and link to lower additional willingness to pay
Explains income effect (real purchasing power changes)
Explains substitution effect (relative price change)
Links each to downward-sloping demand

entries.prompt:
Using  diagrams,  illustrate  the impact  of the following  on a typical  demand  curve.
i. A decrease  in price
ii. A decrease  in income
iii. An increase  in the desirability  of the good
entries.model_answer:
i.  A decrease in price
ii. A decrease  in income
iii. An increase  in the desirability  of the good
 This is a personal question asking you to reflect upon your own demand preferences. I think for
me, a common  example  of the first option  would  be (most)  foods  whereby  the more  I eat the less
I really want anymore. This is not always the case though – some food products can be quite
addictive  for which  the diminishing  marginal  returns  does  not seem  to be present  (at least  over
low levels of consumption).
An example of the second product could be an addictive good – the more you consume the more
you want  to consume  more.  A more  mundane  example  for me might  be something  like electricity.
I guess I consume quite a lot, but I do not experience diminishing marginal returns. One of the
reasons for this would be because we use electricity in many different ways. I have diminishing
marginal utility in watching television, but if I was getting bored of this maybe I would go online –
both use electricity, but the way I am consuming it is very different (sort of).
mark_scheme: Shows movement along demand curve for price decrease
Shows left shift for income decrease (normal good assumption)
Shows right shift for increased desirability/preferences
Correct labels of axes and equilibrium changes

entries.prompt: Which of the following could explain a rightward shift of the demand curve?
entries.rationale: A rightward demand shift can be caused by an increase in the price of substitutes and a decrease in the price of complements; a change in the good’s own price causes movement along the curve.

Questions:
i. What  are the problems  with trying  to infer a demand  curve  over

ii. Independent  of these  problems,  what  can we intuitively  state  about  the

entries.model_answer:
Below  is an extract  from “Demand  for full-time undergraduate  higher  education
(2013  cycle, March deadline)” produced by UCAS in July 2013:
“In England, the 18 year old application rate in 2013 increases by 0.9 percentage points
to 35.1 per cent. This increase is similar to the typical increases seen between 2006
and 2011, but the application rate remains 2 percentage points below where it would be
if there had been a similarly  typical  increase  of 1 percentage  point  in 2012  as well. The
2013  application  rate is near the highest value recorded in recent cycles.
The application rate from Northern Ireland increases by 1.6 percentage points in 2013
to 48.3 per cent, the highest recorded in the period. In Scotland, application rates
continue the recent trend of increasing slightly (0.3 percentage points per year) to 31.6
per cent, also the highest recorded  in the period.  Application  rates  in Wales  decreased
slightly  (by 0.2 percentage  points) to 29.9 per cent, but this is within the range of
expected year to year variability given the relatively small population and is still near to
the highest value recorded (30.1 per cent in 2012).”
Questions:
i. What  are the problems  with trying  to infer a demand  curve  over different
time periods?  This is a question designed to make you think a little more deeply about the assumptions commonly
made  and taken  for granted  in economics.  Types  of discussions  points  could  include:
• A ‘Veblen good’  where an increase in prices leads to an increase in the quantity demanded.
Typically  these  are thought  to be the case for status  goods  where  owning  it informs observers
that you can afford it.
• Psychological  pricing.  Typically  goods  are priced  in round  numbers  and/or  with  the ending ‘99p’.
The concept behind this is that ‘£x.99’ seems cheaper than ‘£(x+1).00’. This would imply  that the
demand function is  not smooth but  exhibits big  jumps  when  moving across these psychological
barriers.
• Other  causes  for discontinuity  in the demand  function  (that  is, not smooth).  For example if two
goods are very close substitutes, demand for one may be zero if the price goes above a certain
point.
• A normal  good  is one which  as incomes  fall the quantity  demanded  decreases.  This in
principle desc ribes most goods. A possible example is food.
• An inferior  good  is one which  when  incomes  fall demand  increases.  A typical  example  is
food purchased from certain low budget supermarkets (e.g. Aldi).
• A Veblen  good  is one where  as prices  rise the quantity  demanded  rises.  Typical  examples
include status products as discussed above.
ii. Independent  of these  problems,  what  can we intuitively  state  about  the
strength  of the relationship between prices and demand in the higher
education market in England?
iii. Is there  an intuitive  argument  for why higher  education  may be a Veblen  good?
 There is a lot of economic research into the benefit of a university degree. Studies frequently
show that individuals with degrees will earn more over their lifetime than those individuals
without, but why this happens is disputed. One prominent theory suggests that all a degree
provides is a signal to potential employers that highlights that an individual with a higher
education qualification is better than one without. Under this theory were prices to increase the
signal  would  become  more  exclusive  and therefore  be worth  more.  This in theory  could  lead  to an
upward sloping demand curve both for higher education in general but also for individual
institutions.  The problem arises from the fact that it is very hard to appeal to the ‘ceteris paribus’ assumption
that all other  things  are equal.  Over  the course  of a year  many  other  changes have  occurred  other
than a change in prices and as such it is hard (and possibly impossible) to isolate the relationship
between prices and demand.
Demand  for higher  education  in England  does  not seem  to be sensitive  to movements  in prices.
Despite the increase in prices over the time period there has also been an increase in demand
(although at lower rates than would have been anticipated at the old prices).
mark_scheme: Defines law of demand
Explains causality from price changes to quantity demanded
Mentions ceteris paribus

entries.prompt:
What is wrong with this statement?
The market supply for natural gas is the sum of all prices that natural gas producers are
willing and able to sell at for every quantity.
entries.model_answer:
What is wrong with this statement?
The market supply for natural gas is the sum of all prices that natural gas producers are
willing and able to sell at for every quantity.
Solution
The market supply curve displays the total amount of natural gas offered to consumers by
all producers in the market at every price. Since suppliers naturally have different costs of
production, they offer varying quantities of product at each market price. The market
supply for natural gas is thus the sum of the quantities that natural gas producers are
willing and able to sell at every price. If more producers enter the market, the market
supply will increase, and if producers exit the market, the market supply will decrease.
mark_scheme: Correct definition: market supply is sum of quantities supplied at each price
Explains why statement is wrong

entries.prompt:
Briefly explain whether each of the following represents a shift in supply or a change in
quantity supplied. Use a graph to illustrate your answer.
a. An increase in the use of corn in the production of ethanol has raised the cost of corn to
farmers who use it as livestock feed.
b. Speculators in world steel markets push the price of steel up, leading American steel
companies to expand production.
entries.model_answer:
Briefly explain whether each of the following represents a shift in supply or a change in
quantity supplied. Use a graph to illustrate your answer.
a. An increase in the use of corn in the production of ethanol has raised the cost of corn to
farmers who use it as livestock feed.
b. Speculators in world steel markets push the price of steel up, leading American steel
companies to expand production.
Solution
a) In the market for corn, increased demand for corn used in the production of ethanol has
driven the price of corn up. For farmers whose output is beef, corn is an input for their
livestock. When the price of an input increases, supply decreases, represented by a leftward
shift of the supply curve.
b) Increased demand in the commodities market has increased the price of steel. As a result,
American steel producers increase their quantity supplied by moving along their supply
curve to the higher price.
mark_scheme: Classifies each event as shift vs movement along supply
Provides correct direction and reasoning using costs/price changes
